awd_titl_txt: Green's Functions and the Nuclear Many-Body Problem
awd_abstract_narration:
The properties of nuclei with large or small neutron to proton ratios are becoming available for experimental scrutiny at facilities like the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB) under construction on the campus of Michigan State University. Most of the experimental probes to study these exotic nuclei involve particles that interact strongly themselves, making it difficult to extract the properties of individual protons or neutrons in these exotic systems. This project aims at overcoming this difficulty by providing a simultaneous description of positive energy nucleons, the domain of elastic scattering, and bound nucleons, the domain of nuclear structure, using the framework of the propagator method of quantum mechanics. This approach will provide critical insight into the properties of very neutron-rich nuclei, and is therefore relevant for the physics of neutron stars by clarifying where neutrons are found with respect to the distribution of protons. The PI will mentor graduate students in this research and collaborate with experimental colleagues who will perform related experiments.

The propagator method will be utilized with non-local potentials constrained by experimental data that allow for the accurate description of ground-state properties of nuclei by the method of dispersion relations. Simultaneously, this implementation will be able to describe or predict all relevant experimental data in the continuum including elastic scattering cross sections. It will therefore be possible to study various nuclear reactions using the ingredients of this method in analogy to the successful analysis of electron-induced proton knockout reactions, thereby clarifying the properties of protons and neutrons in exotic nuclei as well as suggesting relevant new experiments. In particular, the prediction of the neutron distribution for nuclei with excess neutrons will be of critical importance for experiments at Jefferson Lab and future experiments at FRIB. The propagator method will also be employed to calculate the properties of nuclei by starting from the underlying interactions between nucleons as constrained by the symmetries of the fundamental theory of quarks and gluons, Quantum Chromo Dynamics, and the available data for the properties of two nucleons. Such calculations will be applied with a new scheme that allows the ab initio calculation of properties of heavier nuclei that have not been studied in this way to date.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main science question addressed during the recent funding period includes: How do the properties of protons and neutrons in the nucleus change from the valley of stability, where stable nuclei exist, to the respective drip lines with extreme neutron to proton ratios where neutrons or protons no longer remain attached to the nucleus? In the case of a large neutron to proton ratio such systems start to exhibit properties related to those found in the remnants of supernova explosions that result in neutron stars. The answer to this question is addressed by studying the propagation of a proton or a neutron through a stable nucleus at positive energy that generates experimentally accessible elastic scattering data as well as the movement of nucleons in the ground state at negative energy. The latter information sheds light on the density distribution of both protons and neutrons relevant for clarifying properties of the equation of state of neutron stars. Detailed knowledge of this propagation process allows for an improved description of other nuclear reactions, including those that purport to extract nucler structure information, like transfer or knockout reactions. Structure information associated with the removal of nucleons from the target nucleus, is therefore subject of these studies and must be supplemented by the appropriate description of the hadronic reaction utilized to extract it.

Important progress has been achieved during the recent grant period in establishing a unified description of properties of nucleos bound in the nucleus and those that propagate through the nucleus with positive kinetic energy. The method is known as the dispersive optical method (DOM) and succeeds in describing these processes simultaneously using the causality relation between the real and imaginary part of the potential that nucleons experience in the nucleus. Using the resulting ingredients it was possible for the first time to correctly describe the results of electron induced proton knockout reactions on 40Ca and 48Ca that were studied in the past. The results further support the interpretation of this reaction but provide quantitatively accurate results for the removal probability of protons that are the most weakly bound in these nuclei. These probabilities are about 30% smaller that full occupation of the corresponding shell model expectation confirming earlier prediction of theoretical work in our group.

The electron induced proton knockout reaction is only available for stable nuclei so an alternative nuclear reaction for unstable nuclei must be employed to address the experimental answer to our main scientific question. The most attractive reaction involves beams of unstable isotopes impinging on a hydrogen target which represent the equivalent in inverse kinematics of the reaction in which a proton knocks out another proton which are then simultaneously detected. This socalled (p,2p) reaction has subsequently been studied in collaboration with researchers from Japan. The results indicate that additional developments in theory are needed before this reaction can generate unambiguous results for removal probabilities of protons in unstable nuclei.

The outcome of applying the DOM to various nuclei has also been to allow predictions of the neutron distribution as compared to a successful reproduction of the charge distribution. The answer whether neutrons prefer to gather where protons are or will extend outward from them in nuclei with larger numbers of neutrons than protons, provides fundamental insights into the properties of neutron stars. The experimental answer to this question has been obtained at the Jefferson Lab electron facility in Virginia by employing parity-violating elastic electrons scattering experiments on 208Pb and 48Ca. Our result accurately predicted the result for the heavier nucleus but overestimates the other one. This appears to be the case for any theoretical approach that generates results for the socalled neutron skin of both nuclei. Our group is committed to further study this important puzzle.

Another ground breaking result from our studies involves the characterization of the idealized system referred to as nuclear matter. This abstraction of real nuclei involves taking the large particle number limit of the relation that empirically reproduces the energy of the ground state of all nuclei while removing the Coulomb contribution and stipulating the proton and neutron numbers are the same. The resulting nuclear matter is characterized by its density and it binding energy. Experimental access to the density is provided by result for charge densities in the interior of heavy nuclei and corresponds to about 0.16 nucleons per fm3. The binding energy per particle of nuclear matter is extrapolated from the empirical mass formula. Our DOM results have now provided new evidence that this extrapolation lacks sufficient rigor to be reliable. Insteas of the approximately 16 MeV binding we predict about 13-14 MeV is required as our result give an accurate description of the energy of several key nuclei. This important result also has consequences for the interpretation of the energy as a function of density of the interior of neutron stars.
